{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3502613,"name":"Deniz Tirol","username":"Senyo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/senyo/{size}/237589_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T11:29:06.726Z","cooked":"

What is your recommendations about wiring the elevators, what cable protectors should we use and what can we do for preventing cable confusion, how exactly we should wire ?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T11:29:06.726Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":143,"reads":636,"readers_count":635,"score":842.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485268,"topic_slug":"wiring-the-elevators","display_username":"Deniz Tirol","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61989,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Electrical Lead of '8557', Drive Team"},"post_url":"/t/wiring-the-elevators/485268/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3502637,"name":"Kevin Chen","username":"Kevin_Chen","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/c89c15/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T12:39:33.091Z","cooked":"

I would definitely recommend energy chain it protects your cables and if mounted properly it does not get caught on anything. Plus, it moves with your stages. My team drills a big hole for rubber gromets, and we run our wires into the tube first then into the energy chain. As for cable labeling, we usually number our wires at multiple points, especially at connections.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T12:42:13.916Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":618,"readers_count":617,"score":193.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":485268,"topic_slug":"wiring-the-elevators","display_username":"Kevin Chen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/products/energy-carriers/cable-and-hose-carriers-1~/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":142},{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/products/grommets/?s=rubber+grommets","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":47},{"url":"https://www.mcmaster.com/products/wire-labels/adhesive-back-wire-marker-books-with-assorted-characters/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"McMaster-Carr","clicks":20}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31794,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 333 Alumni"},"post_url":"/t/wiring-the-elevators/485268/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3502644,"name":"","username":"Wills1418","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T12:44:06.977Z","cooked":"

For wiring the elevators I would say minimal is best. Try to have the least amount of wires going up as you can. For example if you have motors in the elevators I would put the spark maxes up with them or use a motor that has it built in. For cable protection I would use something like this

encased in a hard shell wire protecter that can bend.
For cable confusion something really helpful I found is using multicolored zip-ties or tape.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T12:44:06.977Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":609,"readers_count":608,"score":151.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":485268,"topic_slug":"wiring-the-elevators","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71305,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/wiring-the-elevators/485268/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3502686,"name":"Egem","username":"egemkercek","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/ec9cab/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T13:56:30.340Z","cooked":"

Before we started wiring our elevator, we were respectively 1 week ahead of our build schedule but we lost a lot of time at wiring, so my advice is plan your wiring before starting. Energy chain wiring is hard to accomplish if you are wiring it for the first time, and we lost 1 week because of it. Label all of the wires going into the energy chain as you move forward and be careful when you try to squeeze the cables into it, they can get damaged very easily because of the nature of the energy chain.
For the labeling, I highly recommend marking the ends of the wires with electric tapes or zipties, so that you know which red and black cables are couples.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T13:56:30.340Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":536,"readers_count":535,"score":202.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485268,"topic_slug":"wiring-the-elevators","display_username":"Egem","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63023,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"egembuildthespeaker"},"post_url":"/t/wiring-the-elevators/485268/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3502784,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-05T15:50:24.803Z","cooked":"

Note that energy chain is an option, but it is a mechanical part of your robot, and needs to be designed as such.

If you’re planning on having a quick elevator, keep in mind that lightweight energy chain isn’t intended to move that fast in compression – large acceleration makes the chain buckle and the hinge joints pop apart. You can make it work, but it requires even more mechanical design work and precision. See: 2910’s 2023 robot; the energy chain was kept under tension.

Also, the energy chain you received in the kit is pretty limited in how much wire it can carry. You might be able to squeeze 2x 14 AWG super-flexible wires into it, maybe add 2x 22 AWG for signal too, but you can’t put 2x 12 AWG 19-strand wires into it and expect it to work, let alone more. The size of the opening is not the carrying capacity of the chain, and if you overfill it, you will start popping the joints on links. Bigger stuff is available, though – check McMaster, for instance.

If you are new to running electrical wiring up elevators, consider coiled cable. It’s not as elegant, and it’s not inexpensive, but it’s more forgiving.

Kevin_Chen:

protects your cables and if mounted properly it does not get caught on anything

You are missing one of its biggest benefits…

It keeps the wires constrained on an axis, so they don’t flop left and right.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-05T17:50:14.769Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":381,"readers_count":380,"score":126.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485268,"topic_slug":"wiring-the-elevators","display_username":"Brandon King","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65629,"username":"chiyo","name":"Chiyo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/6a8cbe/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19708,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2910 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/wiring-the-elevators/485268/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3503599,"name":"Everett33","username":"Everett33","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/everett33/{size}/5027_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-06T00:22:53.424Z","cooked":"

Use Igus or another brand of wire energy chain. You will want to use a much sturdier series than what has been included in the kit of parts for many years. If you are running a swerve drive and use a weaker series of chain, the potential sideways impacts on the robot will shock the chain in directions it is weak in and the links will pop apart or worse, break. We are using Igus E14 series this year after having used E08 series in 2023. The E08 series started breaking down later into the season.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-02-10T03:31:10.422Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":203,"readers_count":202,"score":60.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":485268,"topic_slug":"wiring-the-elevators","display_username":"Will C","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"Regular","title_is_group":false,"reply_to_user":{"id":46443,"username":"Weldingrod1","name":"Rod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66211,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design"},"post_url":"/t/wiring-the-elevators/485268/13","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3521925,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-10T04:00:09.383Z","cooked":"

You can see the two bent plastic guides (with flanges) for the left edge of our chain. The moving part has a tail going down as far as possible.
